url.imageAlt: A clipping of a AIDS Committee of Windsor Monthly Newsletter which showcases a picture of a CHOK 1070 radio panel and a caption that reads “AIDS Awareness was October 11-17, and the AIDS Committee of Windsor held a number of forums in an effort to “Get the Facts” out to the public. The above photo was taken at a public forum on AIDS at SCITS Secondary School in Sarnia. The event was broadcast live on CHOK-AM 1070 Radio. The panelists were, from left, Brother Anthony, the Medical Officer of Health for Lambton County Dr. Lucy Duncan, the moderator from CHOK Peter Henderson, Dr. Brad Munt, and ACW Public Education Director Kevin Bishop. See page three for a complete list of AIDS Awareness Week events”
The Aids Committee of Windsor logo

description: This is the home of Pozitive Pathways, an orginzation that provides client advocacy, support, harm reduction, health promotion, and education services for people living with, affected by, or at-risk of HIV, Hepatitis C and other sexually transmitted blood borne infections (STBBIs) in Windsor-Essex and Chatham-Kent. Originally known as the AIDS Commitee of Windsor, its previous office locations included Jim Monk's apartment on College Avenue (1986-1987), 3178 Walker Road (1987), 1586 Wyandotte Street East, Suite 205 (1988-1990), 1050 University Avenue West (1990-1994), 2090 Wyandotte Street East (1994 - 1997), and the Gino Marcus Community Centre at 1168 Drouillard Road (1997-2006). 511 Pelissier Street became its home in 2006. In 2021, they changed their name to Pozitive Pathways.
